author: timbeiko
content:
On another note, we're finally ready to formally propose EIP-1559 for inclusion in London ðŸŽ‰ I've opened an issue for discussion on the next AllCoreDevs: https://github.com/ethereum/pm/issues/254

We ran performance tests using a network with a state comparable to mainnet, with a write-up available here: https://hackmd.io/@timbeiko/1559-perf-test and kept track of all the other bits of work here: https://github.com/ethereum/pm/blob/master/Fee%20Market%20Meetings/mainnet-readiness.md

<@!420951281910284289> has also been collecting various projects' support here: https://github.com/ethereum-cat-herders/1559-outreach

There are still a bunch of small edge-cases to figure out, but we're pretty confident that "It Works" and have implementations of the latest spec nearly done across Besu, Geth (by <@!543900561460822016>) and Nethermind

content: Also: should miners be encouraged to shrink block sizes during contractions and grow block sizes during expansion periods?

author: tkstanczak
content: That could stabilize the gas prices while limiting the state size waste on low value transactions during the periods of lower economical activity on chain.

author: .vbuterin
content: I actually don't think the issue is coding vs econ expertise per se. I think the issue is more that on coding questions, generally people who are not committed research/devs don't really have opinions and are fine either way (eg. Eric Conner is not going to get either excited or upset about some random minutiae around binary vs verkle trees), but on economic questions, those affect people's interests deeply and in conflicting ways, and the community _does_ have opinions that it's important to respect, and so core dev technocracy is not so effective

author: timbeiko
content: IMO if we're looking at having the merge in ~12 months, and need EIPs for London in ~1 month, it's unlikely we'd have such a change in that upgrade. That means _at best_, your change goes in ~6 months before the merge, so it seems like a lot of work (and highly contentious/political work!) for a fairly small benefit.
